Description: THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THE THREATS OF TRAFFICKING OF THIS SPECIES FOR THE PET TRADE AND BUSHMEAT. FORMERLY ONE OF THE MOST ABUNDANT TORTOISES IN THE WORLD WITH AN ESTIMATED 12 MILLION INDIVIDUALS, EXPLOITATION FOR THE PET TRADE HAS REDUCED THIS SPECIES BY MORE THAN HALF. CHRONIC THREATS FOR BUSHMEAT AND THE PET TRADE CONTINUE TO DRIVE THIS SPECIES CLOSER TO EXTINCTION. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) RECRUITING AND TRAINING LOCAL COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES FROM TWO DISTRICTS IN MONITORING ACTIVITIES TO ENSURE PROMPT AND ACCURATE REPORTING OF POACHING TO AUTHORITIES  (2) PURCHASING COMMUNICATIONS AND MONITORING EQUIPMENT, LIKE PHONES AND MOTORCYCLES, TO FACILITATE RAPID ALERTS AND REPORTING TO LOCAL AUTHORITIES  AND (3) OBTAINING LEGAL SUPPORT TO PURSUE AND ACCOMPANY POACHING CASES

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION EFFORTS FOR THE OMAN LOGGERHEAD NESTING POPULATION THROUGH SURVEYS TO MONITOR LOGGERHEAD NESTING POPULATION TRENDS AND ADDRESS NESTING BEACH THREATS SUCH AS BEACH DRIVING, LIGHT POLLUTION AND NESTING BEACH TRASH AND ABANDONED FISHING NETS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) IMPLEMENTING STANDARDIZED NESTING BEACH SURVEYS ALONG THE ENTIRE 65 KM OF NESTING BEACH  (2) CONDUCTING ONE COMMUNITY MUNICIPAL BEACH CLEANUP AND TWO FISHING NET CLEANUPS EACH YEAR  AND (3) CONDUCTING OUTREACH AND EDUCATION CAMPAIGNS WITH THE MASIRAH ISLAND COMMUNITY AND GENERAL PUBLIC AND (4) WORKING WITH THE MASIRAH COMMUNITY AND OTHER LOCAL ENTITIES TO ADDRESS THE LIGHT POLLUTION, BEACH DRIVING AND POACHING ISSUES THAT THREATEN NESTS AND NESTING TURTLES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR GENETICS RESEARCH IN THE ASIA PACIFIC TO SUPPORT MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION ISSUES RELATED TO TRAFFICKING AND IDENTIFICATION OF SOURCE POPULATIONS AND DETERMINING GENETIC AND DEMOGRAPHICALLY DISTINCT MANAGEMENT UNITS  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE   1  GENETICS TRAINING WORKSHOP FOR AT LEAST SIX GRADUATE STUDENTS AND RESEARCHERS FROM THE PHILIPPINES, INDONESIA AND VIETNAM   2  ORGANIZING AND FACILITATING IN PERSON MEETINGS TO FOSTER REGIONAL COLLABORATION   3  CREATING AND UPDATING THE REGIONAL ROOKERY BASELINE FOR HAWKSBILLS, LEATHERBACKS AND GREEN TURTLE POPULATIONS USING NEW AND PREVIOUS TISSUE BLOOD SAMPLES  AND  4  TRACING ORIGINS OF SEA TURTLES AND SHELLS PRODUCTS IN THE ILLEGAL TRADE FROM SEIZED SAMPLES AND FROM FISHERIES BYCATCH

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES FOR RECOVERY AND EVENTUAL REESTABLISHMENT IN THE WILD. ONLY A SMALL REMNANT POPULATION OF THIS SPECIES EXISS IN THE WILD DUE TO EXPLOITATION FOR MEAT, WITH MOST OF THIS SPECIES RESIDING IN POORLY MANAGED TEMPLE POOLS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) IMPROVING HUSBANDRY PRACTICES IN NAGSHANKA AND HAJOR TEMPLES, INDIA  (2) DEVELOPING HATCHLING GROW OUT AREAS AT THE ASSAM ZOO AND UPGRADING FACILITIES AT THE NATURE DISCOVERY CENTER  (3) TRANSLOCATING 10 NESTS FROM TEMPLES TO THE NATURE DISCOVERY CENTER AND ASSAM ZOO  (4) RELEASING HALF OF THE HATCHLINGS TO SUITABLE RIVERINE HABITAT, REARING THE REMAINING HALF TO 500 GRAMS AND THEN RELEASING ALL BUT 50 WHICH WILL BE HELD IN ASSURANCE COLONIES IN INDIA (5 TRAINING MASTER TRAINERS AT TWO TEMPLES IN POND MAINTENANCE, BASIC MEDICAL AIDE, WATER QUALITY ANALYSES, AND HUSBANDRY PROCEDURES TO ASSIST AND EVENTUALLY HELP IMPROVE TEMPLE PONDS IN THE REGION  AND (6) CREATING AWARENESS PROGRAMS AMONG TEMPLE DEVOTEES, FISHERS AND SCHOOLCHILDREN.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROMOTE RECOVERY OF THE AGST IN CENTRAL LAOS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY BASED SURVEYS WITH SIX VILLAGES AND EDNA SAMPLING BASED ON REPORTED AGST PRESENCE  (2) COMPLETING MARKET SURVEYS AT SIX MARKETS TO DETERMINE EXTENT AND PURPOSE OF TRADE  (3) ORGANIZING A WORKSHOP AND PRESENT FINDINGS OF 1 AND 2 TO KEY AGRICULTURE AND FORESTRY AGENCIES  (4) WORKING WITH GOVERNMENT INSTITUTIONS AND THE CENTER OF EXCELLENCE IN BIODIVERSITY, NATIONAL UNIVERSITY OF LAOS TO DEVELOP AN ACTION PLAN FOR BIODIVERSITY THAT INCLUDES THE AGST  (5) TRAINING COMMUNITY MEMBERS FROM TWO VILLAGES IN MONITORING TECHNIQUES TO REPORT SIGHTINGS AND NESTING SITES  AND (6) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS WITH AROUND 600 COMMUNITY MEMBERS (INCLUDING CHILDREN) IN BIODIVERSITY CONSERVATION AND STEWARDSHIP.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO REESTABLISH WILD POPULATIONS THAT HAVE BEEN DEPLETED OR EXTIRPATED DUE TO EXPLOITATION FOR EGGS AND MEAT AND NESTING HABITAT DEGRADATION. WITH ONLY AN ESTIMATED 20 RIVER TERRAPINS LEFT IN THE WILD THE SPECIES IS CONSIDERED FUNCTIONALLY EXTINCT IN THE WILD. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) RELEASING 10 SUB ADULT HEAD STARTED RIVER TERRAPINS WITH SATELLITE TRANSMITTERS TO UNDERSTAND SURVIVAL AND DISPERSAL  (2) MONITORING AND PROTECTING NESTS AT TWO KNOWN HISTORIC NESTING SITES  (3) CONDUCTING AWARENESS WORKSHOPS WITH 100 FISHERS  AND (4) IMPLEMENTING A NEST TURTLE  BUY BACK  PROGRAM TO PREVENT DEATH OR CONSUMPTION OF TURTLES THAT ARE ACCIDENTALLY CAUGHT AS BYCATCH.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COUNTER THREATS OF HABITAT DEGRADATION AND FISHERIES BYCATCH AND ENSURE THE SURVIVAL OF REMNANT POPULATIONS. THIS SPECIES IS THE MOST ENDANGERED TURTLE IN BRAZIL, WHERE IT IS ENDEMIC. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) DEVELOPING A MANAGEMENT PLAN AND HABITAT RESTORATION PROGRAM FOR THE NINHO DA TARTARUGA RESERVE;(2) INITIATING A POPULATION MONITORING PROGRAM IN THE RESERVE; (3) CONSTRUCTING A NURSERY TO PROVIDE NATIVE PLANTS TO RESTORE STREAMBANK HABITAT FOR THIS SPECIES; (4) ESTABLISHING A HOOK REPLACEMENT PROGRAM WITH LOCAL FISHERS (FROM COMMON "J" HOOKS TO CIRCLE HOOKS WHICH ARE LESS DAMAGING TO ACCIDENTALLY CAPTURED TURTLES); AND (5) INITIATING SURVEYS IN AREAS NEAR THE RESERVE TO LOCATE OTHER POTENTIAL REMNANT POPULATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HELP CONSERVE SEVEN OF THE WORLD'S MOST CRITICALLY ENDANGERED SPECIES, ONE OF WHICH IS SWINHOE'S SOFTSHELL TURTLE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) SECURING A BREEDING GROUP FOR THE SWINHOE'S SOFTSHELL TURTLE WITH ONLY THREE KNOWN LIVING ANIMALS, TWO IN THE WILD AND ONE IN A ZOO IN CHINA; (2) PROMOTING CONSERVATION OF THE INDOCHINESE BOX TURTLE IN PUMAT NATIONAL PARK; (3) BOLSTERING A POPULATION OF BOURRET'S BOX TURTLE THROUGH REINTRODUCTION; (4) INITIATING STEPS TO CREATE AN EXPANDED PROTECTED AREA FOR THE SOUTHERN VIETNAMESE BOX TURTLE; (5) WORKING TO REESTABLISH A WILD POPULATION OF THE ENDEMIC VIETNAMESE POND TURTLE; (6) DETERMINING THE DISTRIBUTION OF ZHOU'S BOX TURTLE IN NORTHERN VIETNAM, WHICH IS ONLY KNOWN FROM ONE CAPTIVE SPECIMEN (7) IDENTIFYING NESTING SITES FOR THE ASIAN GIANT SOFTSHELL TURTLE IN SEKONG RIVER BASIN, LAO PDR.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THREATS TO THIS SPECIES FROM EXPLOITATION FOR MEAT AND MEDICINAL NEEDS. AN ESTIMATED FIVE PERCENT OF THE TOTAL POPULATION IS COLLECTED EACH YEAR WHICH IS STEADILY DRIVING POPULATIONS TOWARDS EXTINCTION. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) DOCUMENTING THE POPULATION STATUS IN TAI, AZAGNY, AND ILES EHOTILE NATIONAL PARKS AND SURROUNDING AREAS THROUGH FIELD SURVEYS; (2) CONDUCTING MARKET SURVEYS IN VILLAGES AROUND THE AFOREMENTIONED PARKS; (3) PROVIDING TURTLES RESCUED FROM BUSHMEAT MARKETS WITH HEALTH CHECKS AND CARE IN PREPARATION FOR TRANSLOCATION TO SOFT RELEASE PENS FOR A MINIMUM OF 12 MONTHS IN SUITABLE HABITAT NEAR PLANNED RELEASE SITES; (4) ENSURING HEALTHY RESCUED TURTLES ARE RELEASED AT SITES IN TAI, AZAGNY, AND ILES EHOTILE NATIONAL PARKS (THE NUMBER IS YET TO BE DETERMINED AND DEPENDS ON HOW MANY WILL BE RESCUED); (5) OUTFITTING AT LEAST 20 OF THE RELEASED RESCUED TURTLES WITH RADIO TAGS AND TRACKING THEM FOR AT LEAST SIX MONTHS TO ASSESS POST-RELEASE BEHAVIORS, ADAPTATION AND SURVIVORSHIP TO INFORM FUTURE RELEASES; AND (6) TRAINING OF PARK PERSONNEL IN SURVEY METHODS, DATA COLLECTION AND RADIO TRACKING TECHNIQUES TO CARRY OUT SURVEY AND PROTECTION WITHIN THE PARKS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO COLLECT FIELD DATA TO DETERMINE THE POPULATION STATUS OF TURTLE SPECIES THREATENED WITH TRAFFICKING FOR THE PET TRADE, AND TO ENGAGE AND BUILD THE CAPACITY OF LOCAL YOUTH IN TURTLE CONSERVATION AND MONITORING EFFORTS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) IMPLEMENTING A SCHOLARSHIP- BASED TRAINING AND MONITORING PROGRAM WITH 24 MIDDLE SCHOOL AND HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS IN TURTLE FIELD STUDIES; (2) MONITORING OF NINE SPECIES AT FIELD SITES TO ESTIMATE POPULATION SIZE; (3) ASSESSING THE POPULATION STATUS OF THE SPOTTED BOX TURTLE AND YUCATAN BOX TURTLE THROUGHOUT THEIR SPECIES RANGE IN MEXICO; AND (4) PRODUCING AND DISTRIBUTING EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ON THESE TURTLES NEAR EACH FIELD SITE.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT THIS SPECIES FROM EXPLOITATION FOR CONSUMPTION BY LOCAL FISHERS AND FOR SALE THIS SPECIES WAS SUSPECTED TO BE EXTINCT IN THE WILD, BUT A POPULATION WAS REDISCOVERED ALONG THE WHITE NILE RIVER IN SOUTHERN SUDAN IN 2017, AND AGAIN IN A REMOTE AREA OF NORTHERN UGANDA IN AUGUST 2021. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) CONDUCTING THREE, 10-DAY FIELD SURVEYS IN NORTHERN UGANDA TO DETERMINE ITS DISTRIBUTION AND POPULATION SIZE; (2) CONSULTING WITH STAKEHOLDERS TO DETERMINE BEST PRACTICES FOR CONDUCTING AN AWARENESS CAMPAIGN WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES; (3) DEVELOPING OUTREACH MATERIALS IN COLLABORATION WITH GOVERNMENT AGENCIES; AND (4) CONDUCTING AWARENESS CAMPAIGNS AND MEETINGS WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY LEADERS AND CITIZENS (INCLUDING YOUTH) TO ASSIST WITH ONGOING COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND AWARENESS FOR PROTECTION OF THIS SPECIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT THE PANCAKE TORTOISE FROM POACHING FOR THE PET TRADE AND DESTRUCTION OF ITS ROCK HABITAT. NATIVE ONLY TO KENYA AND TANZANIA, POPULATIONS OF THIS TORTOISE ARE DECREASING WIDELY THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:(1)CONDUCTING POPULATION SURVEYS TO ASSESS ITS POPULATION STATUS WITHIN THE LEWA-BORANA LANDSCAPE WHICH INCLUDES THREE PROTECTED AREAS; (2) COLLECTING GENETIC SAMPLES TO DETERMINE POPULATION DIVERSITY; (3) PREPARING A LANDSCAPE-SCALE CONSERVATION MANAGEMENT PLAN; AND (4) ANALYZING AND SHARING RECOMMENDATIONS AND CONSERVATION PLANS WITH NEARBY CONSERVANCIES AND PRIVATE RANCHES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO ADDRESS THREATS FROM ILLEGAL FISHING, COLLECTION FOR THE ILLEGAL PET TRADE, AND SAND MINING, AMONG OTHERS, TO ONE OF THE FEW REMAINING WILD POPULATIONS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) RECRUITING AND COMPENSATING COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO ASSIST WITH IN SITU NEST SURVEILLANCE  (2) RELEASING ABOUT 50 HEAD STARTED TURTLES WITH AN INVITATION TO THE ROYAL FAMILY AND A WELL KNOWN BUDDHIST MONK TO PARTICIPATE IN THE PUBLIC RELEASE BLESSING TO MAXIMIZE PUBLIC AWARENESS AND SUPPORT  (3) DEPLOYING SONIC TRANSMITTERS AND RECEIVERS TO TRACK DISPERSAL, HABITAT USE AND SURVIVAL OF RELEASED TURTLES TO INFORM CONSERVATION EFFORTS  AND (4) CONDUCTING AN AWARENESS PROGRAM FOCUSED ON SIX KEY VILLAGES CLOSE TO IMPORTANT NESTING BEACHES TO INCREASE COMMUNITY SUPPORT.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES FOR RECOVERY AND REESTABLISHMENT OF THESE POPULATIONS IN THE WILD. CURRENTLY, ONLY FRAGMENTED REMNANT POPULATIONS OF THIS SPECIES REMAIN IN THE WILD DUE TO HUNTING AND DEGRADED HABITAT FROM RAPID LAND USE CHANGE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) SURVEYING EXTANT POPULATIONS AND IDENTIFYING POTENTIAL RELEASE SITES IN NAGALAND, INDIA  (2) IMPROVING EXISTING FACILITIES WHERE CAPTIVE COLONIES ARE MANAGED TO IMPROVE HATCHING SUCCESS OF EGGS  (3) IMPLEMENTING BEHAVIORAL ENRICHMENT PRACTICES WITH CAPTIVE TORTOISES, LIKE INTRODUCING SENSORY OR FEEDING STIMULI, TO IMPROVE HEALTH AND POST RELEASE SURVIVORSHIP  (4) CONDUCTING AWARENESS ACTIVITIES USING A COMMUNITY BASED PARTICIPATORY APPROACH NEAR POTENTIAL RELEASE SITES  (5) TRAINING 10 YOUTH FROM INDIGENOUS COMMUNITIES TO PARTICIPATE IN PROJECT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES AS  PARA BIOLOGISTS   (6) CONSTRUCTING SOFT RELEASE PENS FOR PRE RELEASE CONDITIONING AND ACCLIMATION  AND (7) RELEASING 10 TORTOISES INTO THE WILD IN BANGLADESH WITH RADIO TRANSMITTERS TO BE MONITORED BY  PARA BIOLOGISTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO PROTECT THIS SPECIES FROM EXPLOITATION FOR EGGS AND MEAT. THIS SPECIES  RANGE DISTRIBUTION HAS BEEN REDUCED BY 97 PERCENT AND IS NOW KNOWN TO RESIDE IN THE WILD IN A 600 KM STRETCH OF THE CHAMBAL RIVER WITH AN ESTIMATED POPULATION OF 500 FEMALES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) OBTAINING 50 CAPTIVE REARED TURTLES FROM THE MADRAS CROCODILE BANK TRUST ASSURANCE COLONY FOR A PILOT REINTRODUCTION IN THE CHAMBAL RIVER (20 TURTLES) AND TO AUGMENT THREE TURTLE SURVIVAL ALLIANCE INDIA CAPTIVE BREEDING COLONIES (30 TURTLES)  (2) QUARANTINING TRANSFERRED TURTLES FOR 90 DAYS AND CONDUCTING HEALTH ASSESSMENTS AT THE TURTLE SURVIVAL ALLIANCE GARAITA FACILITY  (3) CONDUCTING SURVEILLANCE AND NET REMOVAL ALONG A 25 KM STRETCH OF THE CHAMBAL RIVER PLANNED FOR REINTRODUCTION, AS WELL AS WORKING WITH FISHERS IN THIS STRETCH OF RIVER TO MINIMIZE NET DEPLOYMENT AND TURTLE CAPTURES  (4) CONDUCTING COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND AWARENESS IN VILLAGES WITHIN THIS SAME STRETCH OF RIVER  AND (5) RELEASING 20 TURTLES WITH SONIC TRACKING DEVICES TO ASSESS DISPERSAL AND SURVIVAL FOR PILOT REINTRODUCTION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION PROGRAM TO ADDRESS THREATS FROM EGG HARVESTING AND FISHERIES BYCATCH IN THE MIDDLE MAGDALENA RIVER, AND NEST FLOODING IN THE LOWER SINU RIVER DUE TO HYDROELECTRIC DAM RELEASES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) AUGMENTING HATCHLING RECRUITMENT BY INCREASING NEST RESCUES ALONG 5 KM OF RIVER NESTING HABITAT PRONE TO FLOODING ON THE SINU RIVER  (2) RELEASING HATCHLINGS FROM EX SITU MANAGEMENT OF RESCUED NESTS AT SUITABLE SITES  (3)CONDUCTING OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND FISHERMEN  (4)DEVELOPING CONSERVATION AGREEMENTS WITH FISHERS TO MINIMIZE CAPTURES, RELEASE ACCIDENTALLY CAPTURED TURTLES, AND IDENTIFY AND ESTABLISH PROTECTED NESTING AND FORAGING SITES  AND (5) CONDUCTING CAPTURE AND RECAPTURE SAMPLING AT TWO SITES EACH YEAR TO MONITOR POPULATION SIZE, STRUCTURE AND SURVIVAL.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO REDUCE THE ILLEGAL SALE AND TRAFFICKING OF MEAT FROM SEVERAL SPECIES OF ENDANGERED SOFTSHELL TURTLES INCLUDING THE NARROW HEADED SOFTSHELL TURTLE, INDIA SOFTSHELL TURTLE AND PEACOCK SOFTSHELL TURTLE WITHIN A HOTSPOT HOSTING SOME OF THE LARGEST MEAT MARKETS ALONG THE INDO BANGLADESH BORDER. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) CONDUCTING INTERVIEWS WITH INFORMANTS AND STAKEHOLDERS AND SYNTHESIZING AND ANALYZING THESE DATA, ALONG WITH TEN YEARS OF SEIZURE DATA, TO INFORM THE DEVELOPMENT OF DEMAND REDUCTION ACTIVITIES, AND 2) IMPLEMENTING DEMAND REDUCTION ACTIVITIES, LIKE BEHAVIOR CHANGE CAMPAIGNS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO HELP CONSERVE THE ROTE-ISLAND SNAKE-NECKED TURTLES IN INDONESIA WHICH IS LIKELY EXTINCT IN THE WILD DUE TO TRAFFICKING FOR THE PET TRADE AND HABITAT LOSS AND DETERIORATION OF ITS NATIVE LAKE HABITAT. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) TRANSFERRING CAPTIVE HELD TURTLES FROM SINGAPORE TO KUPANG, INDONESIA TO ESTABLISH A CAPTIVE BREEDING PROGRAM; (2) DEVELOPING A MANAGEMENT PLAN WITH STAKEHOLDERS FOR RESTORATION OF LAKE HABITAT AND REESTABLISHMENT OF WILD POPULATIONS; (3) REASSESSING THE READINESS OF THREE POTENTIAL RELEASE SITES, AND (4) CONDUCTING THE FIRST RELEASE TRIALS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE CONSERVATION OF THE BOLSON TORTOISE, WHOSE RANGE IS RESTRICTED TO A REGION OF NORTHWEST MEXICO IN A REMOTE AREA WITH ROUGH TERRAIN WHICH MAKES IT DIFFICULT TO SURVEY WITH FOOT SURVEYS, THROUGH DEVELOPMENT OF PRACTICAL AND COST-EFFECTIVE POPULATION MONITORING. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) DEVELOPING A DRONE SURVEY METHODOLOGY AND INTEGRATED SOFTWARE SYSTEM; (2) IMPLEMENTING THE METHODOLOGY IN A 6-8 KM2 TEST AREA IN MEXICO; (3) DEVELOPING A POPULATION MONITORING PLAN; (4) TRAINING A BIOLOGIST IN MEXICO TO USE THE DRONE AND METHODOLOGY TO IMPLEMENT FUTURE SURVEYS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPROVE THE CARE OF CONFISCATED TURTLES THAT ARE ILLEGALLY TRADED FOR MEAT, TRADITIONAL MEDICINE, AND THE PET TRADE TO INCREASE SURVIVORSHIP. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) STRENGTHENING A RAPID RESPONSE TEAM FOR EFFICIENT ONSITE PRIMARY CARE AND TRIAGE OF CONFISCATED TURTLES  (2) DEVELOPING A TEMPORARY HOLDING AREA FOR CONFISCATED TURTLES AT FOUR KEY LOCATIONS  (3) TRANSLOCATING AND REHABILITATING INJURED OR MORIBUND TURTLES AT THE KUKRAIL GHARIAL AND TURTLE REHABILITATION CENTER  (4) COLLABORATING WITH AUTHORITIES TO REPATRIATE ILLEGALLY TRADED AND CONFISCATED TURTLES AS APPROPRIATE  (5) IMPROVING THE CAPACITY OF GOVERNMENT PARTNERS IN SPECIES IDENTIFICATION, THE INDIAN WILDLIFE PROTECTION ACT, AND PROCEDURES AND DATA MANAGEMENT OF SEIZURE CASES  (6) TRAINING LOCAL VETERINARY, ANIMAL HUSBANDRY PROFESSIONALS AND YOUTH IN TURTLE BIOLOGY, CARE, MANAGEMENT, PAIN RELIEF, AND REHYDRATION TECHNIQUES THAT CAN BE USED DURING TURTLE SEIZURES  AND (7) DEVELOPING MATERIALS FOR TRAINING AND RESCUE OPERATIONS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT THE PLOUGHSHARE TORTOISE (PT), MADAGASCAR BIG HEADED TURTLE (MBHT) AND THE FLAT TAILED TORTOISE (FTT) POPULATIONS FROM POACHING FOR INTERNATIONAL TRAFFICKING FOR THE PET TRADE, EXPLOITATION FOR MEAT AND EGGS, AND HABITAT LOSS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE  (1) SUPPORTING COMMUNITY LED MONITORING ACTIVITIES IN BALY BAY NATIONAL PARK  (2) CONDUCTING A RANGE WIDE SURVEY AND DEVELOPMENT OF A SPECIES ACTION PLAN FOR MBHT, AND NEST PROTECTION FOR MBHT IN TWO NATIONAL PARKS  (3) IMPLEMENTING SUPPLEMENTARY RELEASES OF 114 CAPTIVE BRED MBHT IN THE ANKARAFANTSIKA WETLANDS  (4) COMPLETING SURVEYS FOR FTT AT POTENTIAL RELEASE SITES AND REINTRODUCTION OF 50 CAPTIVE FTT AT VIABLE SITES WITH FOLLOW UP RADIO TRACKING ASSESSMENTS  AND (5) IMPLEMENTING MAINTENANCE OF CAPTIVE POPULATIONS OF ALL THREE SPECIES AT THE CHELONIAN CAPTIVE BREEDING CENTRE IN AMPIJOROA.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION PROGRAMS TO REDUCE THE DEMAND FOR TORTOISES AND FRESHWATER TURTLES (TFT) FOR FOOD, MEDICINE AND PETS IN CHINA, THE WORLD'S LARGEST CONSUMER OF TRAFFICKED TFT. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) REVIEWING CHINA'S REGULATIONS ON TFT FARMING AND TRADE; (2) BUILDING THE CAPACITY OF CIVIL SOCIETY TO SUPPORT TFT CONSERVATION AND MONITORING; (3) PROVIDING INFORMATION TO IMPROVE TRAINING MATERIALS FOR CUSTOMS AGENTS AND OTHER RELEVANT PERSONNEL IN PRIORITY AREAS OF GUANGDONG, GUANGXI AND FUJIAN IN ORDER TO BOLSTER THEIR SURVEILLANCE CAPACITY; AND (4) WORKING WITH BEHAVIORAL INSIGHTS TEAM (A LEADING ORGANIZATION THAT GENERATES BEHAVIORAL INSIGHTS FOR SOCIAL CHANGE) TO DESIGN AND CONDUCT A DEMAND REDUCTION CAMPAIGN TARGETING SPECIFIC POPULATIONS IN LOCATIONS OF HIGH TFT TRADE, E.G. GUANGDONG PROVINCE.

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO HELP CONSERVE THE REMAINING POPULATIONS OF THIS SPECIES IN PENINSULAR MALAYSIA. WILD POPULATIONS HAVE BEEN EXTIRPATED OR DEPLETED BY CONSUMPTION OF EGGS AND MEAT AND NESTING HABITAT DESTRUCTION FROM SAND MINING THROUGHOUT ITS REMAINING RANGE IN SOUTHERN THAILAND, CAMBODIA, AND PENINSULAR MALAYSIA. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) COLLECTING AND RELOCATING 800 WILD RIVER TERRAPIN EGGS TO AN EX-SITU HATCHERY TO LOWER RISKS FROM PREDATION AND POACHING; (2) HEAD-STARTING 500 HATCHLINGS FOR REINTRODUCTION INTO THE WILD; (3) REDUCING ILLEGAL HARVESTING OF EGGS THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED MONITORING PROGRAMS ALONG THE KEMAMAN RIVER; (4) WORKING WITH LOCAL VILLAGERS TO REMOVE MORE THAN 500 KG OF DISCARDED AND ILLEGAL FISHING GEAR IN THE KEMAMAN RIVER; (5) COMPILING DATA ON POACHING AND ILLEGAL TRADE OF THIS SPECIES INTO A DOCUMENT TO PRESENT TO KEY AUTHORITIES TO INFORM EFFECTIVE CONSERVATION INTERVENTIONS; AND (6) DEVELOPING OUTREACH AND EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS FOR TARGET AUDIENCES ON RIVER TERRAPIN HABITAT, THREATS AND PROTECTED STATUS, AS WELL AS SOLUTIONS NEEDED FOR RECOVERY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES TO RECOVER WILD POPULATIONS FROM THE THREAT OF EXPLOITATION FOR EGGS AND MEAT. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) MAINTAINING THE HEALTH OF THE CAPTIVE BREEDING STOCK THROUGH OPTIMAL DIET AND POND MAINTENANCE TO MAXIMIZE REPRODUCTIVE OUTPUT; (2) CAPTURING 10 WILD RIVER TURTLES FOR COMPARATIVE STUDIES OF RELEASED HEAD-STARTED TURTLES; (3) RELEASING 40 HEAD-STARTED TURTLES AND 10 WILD-CAUGHT TURTLES WITH SONIC RADIO TAGS AT TWO SITES TO ASSESS RECRUITMENT SUCCESS OF HEAD-STARTED TURTLES; AND (4) IMPLEMENTING AN EXPANDED NATIONAL AWARENESS CAMPAIGN AND DISTRIBUTING AN EDUCATIONAL TOOLKIT FOR TEACHERS TO USE IN SCHOOLS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES IN COLLABORATION WITH LOCAL ZENU COMMUNITIES TO PROTECT THE CARRANCHINA TURTLE. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) STRENGTHENING THE CAPACITY OF 1,000 RIVERINE INDIGENOUS ZENU PEOPLE IN FRESHWATER TURTLE CONSERVATION PRACTICES; (2) CREATING 32 KM2 OF PROTECTED RIVER AND RIVERINE HABITAT FOR NESTING, FORAGING AND MATING OF THIS SPECIES; (3) ESTABLISHING A REGIONAL OFFICE LED BY THE ZENU WITH THE GOAL TO PROTECT FRESHWATER TURTLES ON THE SINU RIVER; AND (4) MONITORING OF 17 KM2 OF RIVERSIDE NESTING ZONES TO PROTECT AGAINST ILLEGAL TRAFFICKING OF THE CARRANCHINA TURTLE AND OTHER TURTLE SPECIES.
CONSERVATION OF THE BURMESE PEACOCK SOFTSHELL TURTLE

THIS PROJECT AIMS TO HELP CONSERVE THE REMAINING POPULATION OF THIS SPECIES, WHICH IS PERIODICALLY DECIMATED BY CATASTROPHIC FIRES THAT KILL LARGE NUMBERS OF TORTOISES. THIS REQUIRES REPOPULATING WITH HEAD-STARTED TURTLES AS NATURAL REPRODUCTION AND GROWTH IS SLOW. THIS SPECIES IS PARTICULARLY VULNERABLE TO EXTINCTION DUE TO ITS LIMITED REMAINING HABITAT IN SOUTH AFRICA, PERIODIC CATASTROPHIC FIRES, AND ITS INABILITY TO REPRODUCE IN CAPTIVITY. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) REPLANTING HERBACEOUS FYNBOS SPECIES THAT ARE EATEN BY OR PROVIDE SHELTER TO THIS TORTOISE; (2) CONSTRUCTING ENCLOSURES TO HOUSE HEAD-STARTED TORTOISES; (3) CONDUCTING FIELD SURVEYS TO DETERMINE THE POPULATION SIZE AND SURVIVAL RATES TO INFORM MANAGEMENT DECISIONS; AND (4) CONDUCTING FIELD STUDIES TO DETERMINE DISTRIBUTION OF TORTOISE FOOD PLANTS AND TORTOISE MOVEMENTS TO PLAN EFFECTIVE TORTOISE RELEASES AND CONTROLLED BURNS.
COMMUNITY-BASED MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION: PROTECTION AND MONITORING OF LEATHERBACK, GREEN, AND HAWKSBILL TURTLES IN THE WESTERN SOLOMON ISLANDS
CONSERVING CRITICALLY ENDANGERED LEATHERBACK & HAWKSBILL MARINE TURTLES ON NICARAGUA'S PACIFIC COAST (II)

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT AND EXPAND EAST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN COLOMBIA AND PANAMA. THE INTENT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR A COMMUNITY BASED LEATHERBACK NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION PROJECT WITH REMOTE COMMUNITIES IN THE DARIEN GAP OF COLOMBIA AND PANAMA.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONDUCT TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR LOCAL COMMUNITY MONITORING TEAMS; 2) LEAD PATROLS TO QUANTIFY AND PROTECT LEATHERBACK NESTING ACITIVITIES ON KEY NESTING BEACHES OF GATO BEACH (PANAMA) AND JURADO BEACH (COLOMBIA); AND 3) FACILITATE BI-NATIONAL COLLABORATION THROUGH MEETINGS WITH NGOS AND GOVERNMENTAL INSTITUTIONS WITH BOTH COUNTRIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION EFFORTS IN THE PHILIPPINES.  THE INTENT IS TO ASSESS THE THREATS OF SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS TO TRAFFICKING AND FISHERIES BYCATCH.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONDUCT RAPID SEA TURTLE FISHERIES BYCATCH ASSESMENTS TO UNDERSTAND EXTENT OF INTERACTION AND MORTALITY RATES ACROSS FOUR PRIORITY AREAS, PUERTO PRINCESA CITY, EL NIDO-TATAY, QUEZON PROVINCE, AND MARINDDUQUE; 2)  EXAMINE LAW ENFORCEMENT RECORDS ON ILLEGAL APPREHENSIONS OF SEA TURTLE TRAFFICKING TO DETERMINE EXTENT, LOCATIONS, DESTINATIONS; AND 3) CONDUCT REGIONAL CONSERVATION GENETICS WORKSHOP TO IMPROVE SAMPLING, STORAGE AND ANALYSIS OF GENETIC MATERIAL TO BETTER INFORM MANAGEMENT ON ORIGINS OF TRAFFICKED SEA TURTLE PRODUCTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN THE SOLOMON ISLANDS. THE INTENT IS TO IMPLEMENT COMMUNITY BASED NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION ACTIVITIES FOR LEATHERBACK, GREEN AND HAWKBILL SEA TURTLES.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONDUCT NIGHTTIME FOOT PATROLS ON ABOUT 10 KM OF NESTING BEACH ON TETEPARE, RENDOVA, AND VANGUNU ISLANDS TO COUNT AND PROTECT NESTS; 2) CONDUCT TRAINING WORKSHOPS FE ON SEA TURTLE BIOLOGY AND CONSERVATION TECHNIQUES FOR FIELD TEAMS TO BUILD CONSERVATION CAPACITY OF RANGERS AND FIELD MONITORS; AND 3) CONDUCT PUBLIC OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES TO FOSTER GREATER AWARENESS FOR THE STEWARDSHIP AND CONSERVATION OF SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE INTER-AMERICAN SEA TURTLE CONVENTION WITH 15 MEMBER PARTIES INCLUDING THE U.S.  THE INTENT IS TO PROMOTE REGIONAL COLLABORATION AND COOPERATION OF SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION WITHIN THE WESTERN HEMISPHERE.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONVENING OF CONFERENCE OF THE PARTIES, SCIENTIFIC AND CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEES AND SUPPORT FOR ASSOCIATED TRAVEL AND TRANSLATION EXPENSES, 2) TRAVEL SUPPORT TO MEET WITH  HIGH LEVEL GOVERNMENTAL DECISION MAKERS IN  RANGE STATE COUNTRIES OF THE HIGHLY ENDANGERED EAST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK SEA TURTLE TO DISCUSS MEASURES TO MINIMIZE ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE OF LEATHERBACKS IN ARTISANAL AND INDUSTRIAL FISHERIES, AND 3)  TRAVEL SUPPORT FOR SECRETARIAT TO MEET WITH HIGH LEVEL GOVERNMENTAL DECISION MAKERS IN WESTERN HEMISPHERE COUNTRIES TO FOSTER NEW COUNTRY MEMBERSHIP

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN GHANA FOCUSED ON LEATHERBACK AND OLIVE RIDLEY SEA TURTLES.  THE INTENT IS TO ADDRESS SEVERE THREATS FROM POACHING OF MEAT AND EGGS OF NESTING TURTLES AND NESTS AND TO WORK WITH ARTISANAL FISHERMAN TO REDUCE ACCIDENTAL BYCATCH.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1)RCONDUCT DAILY NIGHT PATROLS ON 10 KM OF SEA TURTLE NESTING BEACH WITHIN THE MUNI-POMADZE RAMSAR SITE NOVEMBER 15 -FEBRUARY 28 TO PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING FEMALES AND EXPAND TO A 20 KM BEACH IN KETA THAT HAS HIGH LEATHERBACKNESTING ; 2) CONDUCT SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION EDUCATION PROGRAMS IN LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND WEEKLY RADIO PROGRAMS ABOUT WILDLIFE CONSERVATION; AND 3) TRAIN COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CONDUCT SEA TURTLE SURVEYS AND ECOTOURISM TURLE WALKS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION PROGRAM FOR THE EAST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATION. THIS POPULATION WAS THE WORLD'S LARGEST IN THE 1980'S BUT DUE TO KILLING OF NESTING FEMALES, OVERHARVEST OF EGGS AND ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE IN GILL NET AND LONGLINE FISHERIES IT HAS BEEN REDUCED TO LESS THAN 1000 NESTS EACH YEAR IN MEXICO. MEXICO HISTORICALLY ACCOUNTED FOR 90 PERCENT OF THE EAST PACIFIC NESTING POPULATION.  THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION PROGRAM ON TWO KEY NESTING BEACHES IN MEXICO TO PROTECT NESTS.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) PATROLLING MEXIQUILLO AND LAS PLACITAS NESTING BEACHES AT NIGHT THROUGHOUT THE NESTING SEASON TO DETER POACHING AND COUNT NESTS TO MONITOR NESTING TRENDS, AND 2) RELOCATE NESTS THREATENED BY POACHING AND TIDAL INUNDATION TO SECURE BEACH HATCHERIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION PROGRAM THAT WILL CONTRIBUTE TO THE RECOVERY OF THE EAST PACIFIC HAWKSBILL POPULATION, THE SMALLEST AND MOST ENDANGERED HAWKSBILL NESTING POPULATION IN THE WORLD WITH FEWER THAN 700 NESTING FEMALES.  THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT COMMUNITY BASED NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION PROJECTS ON FOUR OF THE MOST IMPORTANT NESTING BEACHES IN EL SALVADOR AND ECUADOR. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE; 1) COMMUNITY BASED PATROLS TO DETER ILLEGAL POACHING OF NESTING FEMALES AND EGGS AND COUNTING OF NESTS TO MONITOR POPULATION TRENDS AT LOS COBANOS AND PUNTA AMAPALA, EL SALVADOR AND MACHALILLA AND EL PELADO IN ECUADOR, AND 2) RELOCATION OF NESTS THREATENED BY POACHING OR TIDAL INUNDATION TO SAFE BEACH HATCHERIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN LIBERIA WITH ON THE GROUND COMMUNITY BASED CONSERVATION PROJECTS.  LIBERIA'S NESTING SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS ARE DEPLETED FROM OVEREXPLOITATION BUT HAS IMPORTANT FORAGING GROUNDS ALONG ITS ENTIRE COASTLINE AND NESTING BEACH HABITAT INTACT AND SUITABLE FOR RECOVERING SEA TULLE POPULATIONS. THE INTENT IS TO WORK WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO PROTECT TURTLES ON NESTING BEACHES FROM POACHING AND WORK WITH FISHERMAN FROM TO SAFELY RELEASE ACCIDENTALLY CAPTURED SEA TURTLES IN FISHING GEAR. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) TRAINING COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CONDUCT DAILY PATROLS ALONG 18 KM OF NESTING BEACH IN RIVER CESS COUNTY TO COUNT AND PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING FEMALES, 2) TRAINING MONITORS TO COLLECT SEA TURTLE BYCATCH DATA AND STRATEGIC FISHERMAN LANDING SITES AND TO WORK TEACH FISHERMAN SAFE HANDLING AND RELEASE TECHNIQUES FOR ACCIDENTAL CAPTURED TURTLES, AND 3)  PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS AT LOCAL SCHOOLS, AND ASSIST COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOOD SOURCES AS A REPLACEMENT FROM TRADITIONAL CONSUMPTION OF TURTLES AND EGGS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION PROGRAM FOR EAST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATION IN COSTA RICA. THE EP POPULATION WAS THE WORLD'S LARGEST IN THE 1980'S WITH AN ESTIMATED 150,000 NESTS ANNUALLY IN MEXICO AND 10,000 NESTS ANNUALLY IN COSTA RICA. THE POPULATION HAS DECLINED PRECIPITOUSLY DUE TO POACHING OF NESTS (AND IN MEXICO NESTING FEMALES ALSO) AND FISHERIES BYCATCH.  NOW FEWER THAN 1000 NESTS ARE RECORDED EACH YEAR IN MEXICO AND FEWER THAN 200 IN COSTA RICA AND THIS PROJECT IS CRITICAL TO PREVENTING THE EXTIRPATION OF THIS POPULATION.  THE INTENTION OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT LEATHERBACK NESTS FROM POACHING, PREDATORS AND TIDAL INUNDATION.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1)  TRAINING FIELD TEAMS TO CONDUCT NIGHTTIME NESTING SURVEY AND PROTECTION PATROLS AT SEVERAL OF THE KEY REMAINING NESTING SITES; PLAYA LANGOSTA, PLAYA NOMBRE DE JESUS, ZAPOTILLA, ONDA AND REAL; 2) RELOCATION OF NESTS TO SAFE BEACH HATCHERIES;  AND 3) ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION AND OUTREACH TO LOCAL SCHOOLS WITH FIELD TRIPS AND A TURTLE FESTIVAL.

THE PURPOSE AND INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO WORK WITH SPANISH GILL NET AND TRAWL FISHERS TO REDUCE MORTALITY AND INJURY TO ACCIDENTLY CAPTURED SEA TURTLES ALONG THE SPANISH MEDITERRANEAN COAST.  JUVENILE LOGGERHEADS FROM THE U.S. NESTING POPUALTION ACCOUNT FOR ABOUT HALF OF LOGGERHEADS INTERACTING WITH FISHERIES IN THE WESTERN MEDITTERANEAN. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) EVALUATE SEA TURTLE BYCATCH IN BOTTOM TRAWL FISHERIES OPERATING IN THE GULF OF CADIZ USING QUESTIONAIRRES AND ON BOARD OBSERVERS; (2) CONTINUE CAPCITY BUILDING OF ARTISANAL, TRAWL AND LONGLINE FISHERMEN TO REDUCE BYCATCH AND INCREASE SEA TURTLE SURVIVAL RATES THROUGH SAFE HANDLING TECHNIQUES; (3) CREATE A TRINATIONAL NETWORK (MOROCCO, PORTUGAL AND SPAIN) TO REDUCE THE BYCATCH IMPACT IN THE GULF OF CADIZ AND STRAIT OF GIBRALTA; AND (4) SUPPORT AWARENESS, EDUCATION AND OUTREACH EFFORTS DIRECTED TOWARDS FISHING COMMUNITIES INCLUDING PUBLICATION OF  'THE TURTLE GAZETTE', PUBLISHED WITH TOPICS FOR FISHERMAN PRACTICAL INTEREST AS WELL AS SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION MESSAGING.

THIS PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN BANGLADESH.  THE INTENT IS TO ADDRESS THREATS FROM POACHING OF EGGS AND ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE AND MORTALITY IN COASTAL GILL NET AND TRAWL FISHERIES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) TRAINING COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO CONDUCT NESTING BEACH SURVEYS AND NEST PROTECTION ALONG THE 250 KM COAST OF COX'S BAZAR AND PARKI BEACH AND EXPANDING TO COVER AN ADDITIONAL 150 KM OF SUITABLE NESTING BEACHSE ; 2)WORKING WITH FISHERMAN TO IMPLEMENT BEST PRACTICES TO REDUCE SEA TURTLE CAPTURE, INJURY AND MORTALITY; 3) PREPARING EDUCATIONAL AND OUTREACH MATERIALS AND CONDUCTING EDUCATION AND AWARENESS PROGRAMS WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES, FISHERMAN AND SCHOOLS; AND 4) COMPLETE CONSTRUCTION OF A SEA TURTLE REHABILITATION CENTER FOR TURTLES INJURED BY BOATS OR ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE IN NETS OR TRAWLS AND WILL ALSO SERVE AS AN EDUCATION CENTER FOR LOCAL PEOPLE AND ATTRACTION FOR TOURISTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROPOSAL IS TO IMPLEMENT A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN EQUATORIAL GUINEA. EQUATORIAL GUINEA HOSTS DEPLETED SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS ON THE MAINLAND DUE TO OVEREXPLOITATION AND IMPORTANT COASTAL FORAGING HABITATS FOR SEVERAL SPECIES OF SEA TURTLES THAT ORIGINATE FROM LARGER NESTING POPULATIONS IN NEIGHBORING COUNTRIES, AND ITS OWN ISLAND WHICH HOSTS REGIONALLY SIGNIFICANT GREEN TURTLE AND LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATIONS. THE INTENTION IS TO ADDRESS THREATS FROM ILLEGAL POACHING OF NESTING TURTLES AND NESTS ON PROTECTED AREAS AND TO ASSESS SEA TURTLE BYCATCH CAPTURE AND MORTALITY FROM FISHING ACTIVITIES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A PARTNERSHIP OF GOVERNMENT, UNIVERSITY, NGO, PRIVATE ENTITIES AND COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN MYANMAR TO RECOVER DEPLETED BUT HISTORICALLY IMPORTANT REGIONAL POPULATIONS OF OLIVE RIDLEY, GREEN AND HAWKSBILL SEA TURTLES. THE INTENT IS TO SUPPORT A NEWLY FORMED SEA TURTLE WORKING GROUP OF THESE AFOREMENTIONED PARTNERS TO DEVELOP A NATIONAL AND GRASSROOTS CONSERVATION PROGRAM TO ADDRESS THE THREATS OF POACHING OF EGGS AND TURTLES AND THREATS OF BYCATCH FROM ARTISANAL AND INDUSTRIAL FISHERIES.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) ORGANIZE THE ANNUAL MEETING OF THE MARINE TURTLE WORKING GROUP OF GOVERNMENT, NGOS, UNIVERSITY AND PRIVATE SEA TURTLE STAKEHOLDERS; 2) CONDUCT TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR SEA TURTLE SURVEYORS IN THREE REGIONAL LOCATIONS OF THE COAST; 3) IMPLEMENT MONITORING AND NEST PROTECTION PROGRAMS AT SIX KEY NESTING SITES; 4) DEVELOP EDUCATION AND AWARENESS MATERIALS ABOUT PROTECTED STATUS OF SEA TURTLES, THREATS AND SAFE RELEASE OF ACCIDENTALLY CAPTURED SEA TURTLES IN FISHING GEAR AND DISTRIBUTE TO FISHERMAN, TRADERS AND AT SCHOOLS; 5) CONTINUE TO ASSESS HATCHERY MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND IMPLEMENT BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES; AND 6) FACILITATE DEVELOPMENT AND IMPLEMENTATION OF NATIONAL ACTION PLAN WITH ALL KEY STAKEHOLDERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN THE REPUBLIC OF CONGO. THE INTENT IS TO CONDUCT NESTING BEACH MONITORING AND NEST PROTECTION WITHIN AND OUTSIDE CONKUATI-DOUALI NATIONAL PARK AND SEA TURTLE BYCATCH REDUCTION PROGRAMS WITH ARTISANAL FISHERMAN. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:1) DAILY EARLY MORNING AND NIGHTTIME NEST SURVEYS ALONG FIVE 10 KM STRETCHES OF BEACH WITHIN CONKUATI-DOUALI NP; 2) DAILY EARLY MORNING AND NIGHTIME MONITORING OF THREE 10 KM STRETCHES OF NESTING BEACHES ON DJENO, BELLELO, AND MVASSA BEACHES OUTSIDE OF THE NP; 3) EARLY MORNING MONTORING OF 42 KM OF ADDITIONAL NESTING BEACHES OUTSIDE OF CONKUATI-DOUALI NP; AND 4) CONDUCTING  A SEA TURTLE RELEASE PROGRAM FOR ACCIDENTALLY CAPTURED TURTLES WITH ARTISANAL GILL NET FISHERMAN IN RETURN FOR PROVIDING NET REPAIR BOBBINS AND NET PIECES.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE PRIMARILY FOCUSED ON PROTECTING AND RECOVERY THE HAWKSBILL POPULATION. SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE HOST THE LARGEST HAWKSBILL NESTING POPULATION ALONG THE AFRICAN ATLANTIC COAST.  THE INTENT IS TO PROTECT HAWKSBILL AND OTHER SEA TURTLES FROM POACHING FOR MEAT, EGGS AND SHELLS.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) CONDUCTING A 6 DAY TRAINING WORKSHOP OF ALL STAFF, RANGERS, AND FIELD ASSISTANTS ON SEA TURTLE BIOLOGY AND FIELD TECHNIQUES, ECOTOURISM AND COMMUNICATION SKILLS; 2) CONDUCTING DAILY NIGHTTIME PATROLS ON 22 KM OF THE MAIN HAWKSBILL NESTING BEACHES OF SAO TOME DURING THE NESTING SEASON, SEPT. 15- APRIL 15; 3) RELOCATING NESTS AS NECESSARY TO BEACH HATCHERIES TO PROTECT FROM POACHING, PREDATORS AND EROSION; 4) CONDUCTING EDUCATION AND AWARENESS ACTIVITIES WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES; 5) SUPPORTING THE SEA TURTLE WOMEN TRADERS ASSOCIATION IN DEVELOPING THEIR SKILLS TO PRODUCE T-SHIRTS, BAGS AND OTHER SOUVENIRS AS AN ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOOD ACTIVITY.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO DEVELOP A SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAM IN LIBERIA WITH ON THE GROUND COMMUNITY BASED CONSERVATION PROJECTS.  LIBERIA'S NESTING SEA TURTLE POPULATIONS ARE DEPLETED FROM OVEREXPLOITATION BUT HAS IMPORTANT FORAGING GROUNDS ALONG ITS ENTIRE COASTLINE AND NESTING BEACH HABITAT INTACT AND SUITABLE FOR RECOVERING SEA TULLE POPULATIONS. THE INTENT IS TO WORK WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO PROTECT TURTLES ON NESTING BEACHES FROM POACHING AND WORK WITH FISHERMAN FROM TO SAFELY RELEASE ACCIDENTALLY CAPTURED SEA TURTLES IN FISHING GEAR. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE:  1) TRAIN COMMUNITY MEMBERS IN THE COMMUNITIES OF BASSA POINT, LITTLE BASSA AND EDINA TO CONDUCT DAILY PATROLS TO COUNT AND PROTECT NESTING SEA TURTLES AND NESTS DURING THE NESTING SEASON, 2) TRAINING MONITORS TO COLLECT SEA TURTLE BYCATCH DATA AND STRATEGIC FISHERMAN LANDING SITES AND TO WORK TEACH FISHERMAN SAFE HANDLING AND RELEASE TECHNIQUES FOR ACCIDENTAL CAPTURED TURTLES, AND 3)  PROVIDE ENVIRONMENTAL EDUCATION PROGRAMS AT LOCAL SCHOOLS, AND ASSIST COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP ALTERNATIVE LIVELIHOOD SOURCES AS A REPLACEMENT FROM TRADITIONAL CONSUMPTION OF TURTLES AND EGGS

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAMS WITHIN THE TRISTAO AND ALCATRAZ MARINE PARK, GUINEA. THE INTENT IS TO WORK WITH LOCAL COMMUNITIES AND PARK RANGERS TO REDUCE ILLEGAL KILLING OF NESTING AND FORAGING GREEN, OLIVE RIDLEY AND HAWKSBILL SEA TURTLES AND POACHING OF NESTS WITHIN THE PARK. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: 1) TAIN COMMUNITY BASED SURVEY TEAM TO CONDUCT YEAR ROUND BEACH MONITORING OF 20 KM OF THE MAIN NESTING BEACH ON KATRACK ISLAND, AND 2) CONDUCT TWO CAPACITY BUILDING TRAINING WORKSHOPS FOR MINISTRY OF ENVIRONMENT AND PARK RANGERS AND FOLLWED BY IN SITU PRACTICAL FIELD WORK WITH RANGERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROGRAMS WITHIN DOUALA-EDEA WILDLIFE RESERVE AND THE PROPOSED MANYANGE NA ELOMBO-CAMPO NATIONAL MARINE PARK, CAMEROON. THE INTENT IS TO WORK WITH THE MINISTRY OF WILDLIFE AND FORESTS (MWF) AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO DEVELOP COMMUNITY BASED NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION PROGRAMS OLIVE RIDLEYS AND LEATHERBACKS AND TO ASSIST LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO ADAPT TO AND SUPPORT THE PROPOSED MARINE PARK. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE; 1) TRAIN AND FIELD COMMUNITY SURVEY TEAMS TO CONDUCT NESTING SURVEYS AND PROTECTION ON THE BEACHES OF DOUALA-EDEA WILDLIFE RESERVE AND PROPOSED MANYANGE MARINE PARK, 2) CONDUCT TWO WORKSHOPS WITH MANYANGE LOCAL COMMUNITIES, TRADITIONAL CHIEFS, NGOS AND CIVIL SOCIETY TO DISCUSS OBJECTIVES OF PROPOSED NATIONAL PARK AND ENGAGING ALL STAKEHOLDERS IN ITS FUTURE MANAGEMENT, 3) ASSIST MWF WITH DEVELOPMENT OF MANAGEMENT PLAN FOR THE MANYANGE NP, 4) CONDUCT OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES WITH VILLAGES WITHIN OR ADJACENT TO DOUALA-EDEA WILDLIFE RESERVE AND MAYANGE NP.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT A CONSERVATION PROGRAM FOR THE SW ATLANTIC OCEAN LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATION THAT NESTS ONLY IN BRAZIL.  THIS IS THE SMALLEST GENETICALLY AND DEMOGRAPHICALLY DISTINCT LEATHERBACK POPULATION IN THE WORLD WITH FEWER THAN 20 FEMALES NESTING EACH YEAR. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO BUILD CAPACITY AND KNOWLEDGE IN SUPPORT OF THE ESTABLISHMENT OF A MARINE PROTECTED AREA TO PROTECT THIS POPULATION FROM FISHERIES BYCATCH MORTALITY AND TO BUILD CAPACITY FOR NESTING BEACH MONITORING AND PROTECTION.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) CHARACTERIZE FISHERIES AND FISHING ACTIVITIES; (2) ANALYZE FISHERIES AND LEATHERBACK SATELLITE TRACKING DATA TO DETERMINE INTERACTION ZONES IN SUPPORT OF THE MPA; (3) CONDUCT TRAINING OF FIELD MONITORS TO IMPROVE CAPACITY FOR DATA COLLECTION AND NEST PROTECTION; AND (4) CONDUCT OUTREACH AND EDUCATION ACTIVITIES INCLUDING  NIGHT PATROLS ON NESTING BEACHES WITH LOCAL COMMUNITY MEMBERS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IMPLEMENT A CONSERVATION PROGRAM FOR NESTING AND FORAGING TURTLES IN THE KALPITIYA PENINSULA. THE INTENT OF THE PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THE THREATS FROM ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE AND RESULTING INJURIES AND MORTALITY FROM LOCAL FISHERIES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE- (1) CONDUCT 12 WORKSHOPS TO TRAIN FISHERMAN IN SAFE HANDLING AND RELEASE OF MARINE TURTLES; (2) CONSULT WITH FISHERMAN TO DEVELOP STRATEGIES AND METHODS TO MINIMIZE CAPTURES OF SEA TURTLES; AND (3) CONDUCT AWARENESS AND OUTREACH CAMPAIGN WITH SCHOOLS, FISHERMAN GROUPS AND LOCAL COMMUNITIES TO RAISE AWARENESS OF SEA TURTLE STATUS AND CONSERVATION ISSUES AS WELL AS COASTAL BIODIVERSITY AND SUSTAINABILITY.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS STRENGTHEN EAST PACIFIC (EP) LEATHERBACK CONSERVATION EFFORTS  THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE (MEXICO TO CHILE). THE EP LEATHERBACK NESTS IN MEXICO, COSTA RICA AND NICARAGUA AND MIGRATES AND FORAGES ALONG THE EAST PACIFIC FROM MEXICO SOUTH TO CHILE. EP LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATION ONCE THE LARGEST NESTING POPULATION IN THE WORLD, WITH OVER 150,000 NEST ESTIMATED IN THE EARLY 1980'S, HAS PLUMMETED TO FEWER THAN 1500 NESTS ANNUALLY. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE EP LEATHERBACK CONSERVATION NETWORK (LAUD OPO) TO IMPROVE NESTING BEACH AND BYCATCH REDUCTION PROJECTS AND TO PROVIDE SCIENTIFIC EXPERTISE TO SUPPORT THE SECRETARIAT OF THE INTER-AMERICAN SEA TURTLE CONVENTION (IAC) IN MEETINGS WITH GOVERNMENT DECISION MAKERS TO ADDRESS BYCATCH REDUCTION MEASURES.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1)  MAINTAIN REGIONAL DATABASE, WEBSITE AND ONLINE LIBRARY OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES FOR LAUD OOP; (2) FACILITATE ALIGNMENT OF IAC LEATHERBACK TASKFORCE PRIORITIES WITH LAUD OPO; (3) ACCOMPANY IAC SECRETARIAT AS TECHNICAL EXPERT TO MEETINGS WITH HIGH LEVEL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS AND INTERNATIONAL FISHERIES BODIES TO ADDRESS LEATHERBACK FISHERIES BYCATCH; AND (4) COORDINATE ONE LAUD OPO WORKSHOP ANNUALLY TO REVIEW ONGOING PROJECTS AND ACTIVITIES AND CONSULT ABOUT PROBLEMS, NEEDS, AND SUCCESSFUL MEANS TO FURTHER RECOVERY EFFORTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT CONSERVATION AND RECOVERY EFFORTS FOR THE WEST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK POPULATION WHICH HAS EXPERIENCED A POPULATION DECLINE OF OVER 80 PER CENT IN THE LAST THREE DECADES DUE TO THREATS FROM PREDATORS, POACHERS, BEACH EROSION, FISHERIES ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE, AND DIRECTED KILLING FOR MEAT.  THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ADDRESS THE DIRECTED TAKE OF LEATHERBACKS FOR MEAT ON THE KEI ISLANDS WHICH IS UNDERMINING NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION EFFORTS AND CONTRIBUTING SIGNIFICANTLY TO THE CONTINUED DECLINE SINCE IT INVOLVES THE HARVEST OF ADULT NESTING FEMALES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1)MONITOR AND ACCURATELY RECORD THE LEVEL OF ANNUAL MORTALITY IN 9 VILLAGES INVOLVED IN THE HUNTING OF LEATHERBACKS FOR MEAT; (2) DEVELOP OUTREACH STRATEGY WITH INPUT FROM COMMUNITIES AND SOCIAL SCIENTISTS THAT ADDRESS THE CULTURAL AND COMMUNITY ATTITUDES AND BEHAVIORS THAT PERPETUATE THE HUNTING OF ADULT LEATHERBACKS FROM THIS DEPLETED LEATHERBACK NESTING POPULATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE MEXICO-US BINATIONAL KEMP'S RIDLEY CONSERVATION PROJECT IN MEXICO. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS NESTING BEACH MANAGEMENT PRACTICES,  PREDATOR THREATS TO NESTS TO INFORM AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND ENHANCE POPULATION RECOVERY. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) ASSESS SEX RATIOS IN HATCHERY AND IN SITU NESTS; (2) ASSESS HATCHING FITNESS FROM HATCHERY AND IN SITU NESTS; (3) ASSESS ARRIBADA NESTING EVENTS USING DRONES; AND (4) ASSESS PREDATOR THREATS TO IN SITU NESTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONTINUE HAWKSBILL CONSERVATION PROGRAMS AT NESTING BEACHES IN BAHIA DE JIQUILISCO BIOSPHERE RESERVE (BAHIA), EL SALVADOR AND ON FORAGING GROUNDS IN EL SALVADOR AND NICARAGUA.  THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING FEMALES FROM POACHING AND ALSO TO WORK WITH LOCAL FISHERMAN TO REDUCE HAWKSBILL BYCATCH FROM LOBSTER FISHERIES. THE SMALL EASTERN PACIFIC HAWKSBILL NESTING POPULATION WAS THOUGHT TO HAVE BEEN EXTIRPATED UNTIL REMNANT POPULATIONS WERE DISCOVERED IN REMOTE SITES UNTIL 2008. BAHIA DE JIQUILISCO ACCOUNTS FOR ABOUT 40 % OF ALL HAWKSBILL NESTING IN THE EAST PACIFIC. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1)  CONDUCT COMMUNITY BASED PATROLS AND RELOCATION OF NESTS TO HATCHERIES;  (2) CONDUCT OUTREACH ACTIVITIES SUCH AS A HAWKSBILL FESTIVAL, HAWKSBILL CUP COMPETITION AND 'DAY OF THE HAWKSBILL' EVENTS IN SCHOOLS TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT THREATS TO HAWKSBILLS; (3) CONDUCT YEAR ROUND FISHERIES BYCATCH MONITORING OF LOBSTER FISHERIES WITH ON BOARD OBSERVERS; (4) CONDUCT LED LIGHT TRIALS ON LOBSTER NETS TO DETERMINE DETERRENCE EFFECTIVENESS; AND (5) DEVELOP LOCAL CAPACITY TO STRENGTHEN A HAWKSBILL ECOTOURISM PROGRAM FOR THE BENEFIT OF LOCAL RESIDENTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO CONDUCT COMMUNITY BASED SEA TURTLE CONSERVATION PROJECTS ALONG NESTING BEACHES ON THE BAY OF BENGAL, INDIA.  THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING TURTLES FROM POACHING AND REDUCE THE ACCIDENTAL CAPTURE AND MORTALITY OF SEA TURTLES IN FISHING TRAWLS. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1)  MEMBERS OF  SEA TURTLE COMMUNITY FORCE TEAMS WILL CONDUCT DAILY SURVEYS TO PROTECT NESTS AND NESTING TURTLES ALONG OVER 500 KM ENCOMPASSING 173 VILLAGES DURING THE DECEMBER TO MAY NESTING SEASON AND PROTECT AN ESTIMATED 6000 NESTS; (2) OUTREACH AND EDUCATION WILL BE CONDUCTED IN 111 FISHING COMMUNITIES TO ADDRESS SEA TURTLE BYCATCH IMPACTING THE MAJOR OLIVE RIDLEY ARRIBADA NESTING POPULATIONS IN THE STATE OF ORISSA, INDIA; (3) CAPACITY BUILDING WORKSHOPS TO TRAIN 1000 ENFORCEMENT OFFICERS FROM WILDLIFE AND FISHERIES INSTITUTIONS, COAST GUARD AND MARINE POLICE IN THE LAWS AND REGULATIONS PROTECTING MARINE LIFE AND SYSTEMS AND TO STRENGTHEN COLLABORATION AMONG THE INSTITUTIONS; AND (4) CONDUCT JOINT TED DEMONSTRATION WORKSHOPS FOR TRAWL FISHERIES WITH FISHERIES AND FORESTRY DEPT.

THE MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION FUND IS SOLICITING PROPOSALS FOR THE CONSERVATION OF MARINE TURTLES (CHELONIA MYDAS, CARETTA CARETTA, DERMOCHELYS CORIACEA, ERETMOCHELYS IMBRICATA, LEPIDOCHELYS OLIVACEA, LEPIDOCHELYS KEMPII) THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES AND ITS TERRITORIES.  THE U.S. GOVERNMENT ENACTED THE MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION ACT (MTCA) OF 2004 IN RESPONSE TO THE DECLINE OF MANY MARINE TURTLE POPULATIONS WORLDWIDE AND THE SERIOUS THREATS TO THEIR LONG-TERM SURVIVAL. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE ACT IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR PROJECTS THAT CONSERVE NESTING POPULATIONS AND HABITAT AND ADDRESS OTHER THREATS TO THE SURVIVAL OF MARINE TURTLES IN FOREIGN COUNTRIES.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO REDUCE THREATS TO MARINE TURTLES IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT.  PROPOSALS SHOULD IDENTIFY SPECIFIC CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT HAVE A HIGH LIKELIHOOD OF CREATING LASTING BENEFITS.  PROJECT ACTIVITIES THAT EMPHASIZE DATA COLLECTION AND STATUS ASSESSMENT SHOULD DESCRIBE A DIRECT LINK TO MANAGEMENT ACTION, AND EXPLAIN HOW LACK OF INFORMATION HAS BEEN A KEY LIMITING FACTOR FOR MANAGEMENT ACTION IN THE PAST.  PROPOSALS THAT DO NOT IDENTIFY HOW ACTIONS WILL REDUCE THREATS OR THAT DO NOT DEMONSTRATE A STRONG LINK BETWEEN DATA COLLECTION AND MANAGEMENT ACTION WILL BE DISQUALIFIED.

PROPOSED PROJECT WORK SHOULD OCCUR WITHIN THE SPECIES RANGE, OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES.  IF WORK IS TO BE CONDUCTED OUTSIDE OF THE SPECIES RANGE, THE PROPOSAL SHOULD SHOW A CLEAR RELEVANCE TO ITS CONSERVATION.

THE MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION FUND IS SOLICITING PROPOSALS FOR THE CONSERVATION OF MARINE TURTLES (CHELONIA MYDAS, CARETTA CARETTA, DERMOCHELYS CORIACEA, ERETMOCHELYS IMBRICATA, LEPIDOCHELYS OLIVACEA, LEPIDOCHELYS KEMPII) THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES AND ITS TERRITORIES.  THE U.S. GOVERNMENT ENACTED THE MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION ACT (MTCA) OF 2004 IN RESPONSE TO THE DECLINE OF MANY MARINE TURTLE POPULATIONS WORLDWIDE AND THE SERIOUS THREATS TO THEIR LONG-TERM SURVIVAL. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE ACT IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR PROJECTS THAT CONSERVE NESTING POPULATIONS AND HABITAT AND ADDRESS OTHER THREATS TO THE SURVIVAL OF MARINE TURTLES IN FOREIGN COUNTRIES.

THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO REDUCE THREATS TO MARINE TURTLES IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT.  PROPOSALS SHOULD IDENTIFY SPECIFIC CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT HAVE A HIGH LIKELIHOOD OF CREATING LASTING BENEFITS.  PROJECT ACTIVITIES THAT EMPHASIZE DATA COLLECTION AND STATUS ASSESSMENT SHOULD DESCRIBE A DIRECT LINK TO MANAGEMENT ACTION, AND EXPLAIN HOW LACK OF INFORMATION HAS BEEN A KEY LIMITING FACTOR FOR MANAGEMENT ACTION IN THE PAST.  PROPOSALS THAT DO NOT IDENTIFY HOW ACTIONS WILL REDUCE THREATS OR THAT DO NOT DEMONSTRATE A STRONG LINK BETWEEN DATA COLLECTION AND MANAGEMENT ACTION WILL BE DISQUALIFIED.

PROPOSED PROJECT WORK SHOULD OCCUR WITHIN THE SPECIES RANGE, OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES.  IF WORK IS TO BE CONDUCTED OUTSIDE OF THE SPECIES RANGE, THE PROPOSAL SHOULD SHOW A CLEAR RELEVANCE TO ITS CONSERVATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO IDENTIFY REMNANT HAWKSBILL NESTING POPULATION ALONG 500 KM OF THAILAND COAST IN WHICH TO ESTABLISH COMMUNITY BASED CONSERVATION PROGRAMS. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT HAWKSBILL NESTS AND NESTING FEMALES FROM POACHING. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: YEAR 1; (1) SYNTHESIZE ALL REPORTED HAWKSBILL NESTING WITHIN PAST 5 YEARS; (2) VISIT COMMUNITIES WHERE NESTING HAS BEEN REPORTED TO CONFIRM RECENT OR CURRENT NESTING AND THREATS THROUGH INTERVIEWS AND CONDUCTING  NIGHT TIME SURVEYS; (3) DURING COMMUNITY VISITS DOCUMENT PRESENCE AND SALE OF HAWKSBILL SHELL AND OTHER SEA TURTLE PRODUCTS; AND (4) SUPPORT 4 THAI REPRESENTATIVES TO PARTICIPATE IN REGIONAL TRAINING WORKSHOP IN CAMBODIA ON SEA TURTLE BIOLOGY AND CONSERVATION METHODS.  YEAR 2:  (1) CONDUCT CAPACITY BUILDING AND TRAINING WORKSHOP FOR 16 PARTICIPANTS FROM FOUR THAI PROVINCES AND ADDITIONAL REPRESENTATIVES FROM THAI NAVY AND DEPT. OF MARINE AND COASTAL RESOURCES THAT ARE OR WILL BE INVOLVED IN ON GROUND NESTING BEACH CONSERVATION PROJECTS.

THE PURPOSE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE MEXICO-US BINATIONAL KEMP'S RIDLEY CONSERVATION PROJECT IN MEXICO. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO ASSESS NESTING BEACH MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, NESTING FEMALE REPRODUCTIVE OUTPUT, AND PREDATOR THREATS TO NESTS, TO INFORM AND IMPROVE MANAGEMENT PRACTICES, AND ENHANCE POPULATION RECOVERY.  ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1) ASSESSING SEX RATIOS IN HATCHERY AND IN SITU NESTS; AND (2) ASSESSING HATCHING FITNESS FROM HATCHERY AND IN SITU NESTS; (3) ASSESSING ARRIBADA SIZE USING DRONES; AND (4) ASSESSING PREDATOR THREATS TO IN SITU NESTS.  


THE GOAL OF THIS PROGRAM IS TO REDUCE THREATS TO MARINE TURTLES IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT.  PROPOSALS SHOULD IDENTIFY SPECIFIC CONSERVATION ACTIONS THAT HAVE A HIGH LIKELIHOOD OF CREATING LASTING BENEFITS.  PROJECT ACTIVITIES THAT EMPHASIZE DATA COLLECTION AND STATUS ASSESSMENT SHOULD DESCRIBE A DIRECT LINK TO MANAGEMENT ACTION, AND EXPLAIN HOW LACK OF INFORMATION HAS BEEN A KEY LIMITING FACTOR FOR MANAGEMENT ACTION IN THE PAST.  PROPOSALS THAT DO NOT IDENTIFY HOW ACTIONS WILL REDUCE THREATS OR THAT DO NOT DEMONSTRATE A STRONG LINK BETWEEN DATA COLLECTION AND MANAGEMENT ACTION WILL BE DISQUALIFIED.

PROPOSED PROJECT WORK SHOULD OCCUR WITHIN THE SPECIES RANGE, OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES.  IF WORK IS TO BE CONDUCTED OUTSIDE OF THE SPECIES RANGE, THE PROPOSAL SHOULD SHOW A CLEAR RELEVANCE TO ITS CONSERVATION.

THE PURPOSE OF THE PROJECT IS TO STRENGTHEN THE EAST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK CONSERVATION PROGRAM THROUGHOUT ITS RANGE. THE EAST PACIFIC LEATHERBACK NESTS IN MEXICO, COSTA RICA AND NICARAGUA AND MIGRATES AND FORAGES ALONG THE EAST PACIFIC FROM MEXICO SOUTH TO CHILE.  THE NESTING POPULATION WAS ONCE THE LARGEST IN THE WORLD, WITH OVER 150,000 NESTS ESTIMATED IN THE EARLY 1980⿿S. THIS HAS PLUMMETED TO FEWER THAN 1500 NESTS ANNUALLY. THE INTENT OF THIS PROJECT IS TO SUPPORT THE EP LEATHERBACK CONSERVATION NETWORK (LAUD OPO) IN ITS EFFORTS TO IMPROVE NESTING BEACH AND BYCATCH REDUCTION PROJECTS AND TO SUPPORT THE SECRETARIAT OF THE INTER-AMERICAN SEA TURTLE CONVENTION (IAC) IN MEETINGS WITH HIGH LEVEL GOVERNMENT DECISION MAKERS TO ADDRESS BYCATCH REDUCTION MEASURES IN RANGE STATE COUNTRIES. ACTIVITIES INCLUDE: (1)  ENSURE REGIONAL DATABASE, WEBSITE AND ONLINE LIBRARY OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES IS MAINTAINED FOR THE EP LEATHERBACK NETWORK; (2) FACILITATE ALIGNMENT OF IAC LEATHERBACK TASKFORCE PRIORITIES WITH EP LEATHERBACK NETWORK AS CHAIR OF THE IAC LEATHERBACK TASK FORCE: (3) ACCOMPANY IAC SECRETARIAT AS TECHNICAL EXPERT TO MEETINGS WITH HIGH LEVEL GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS TO DISCUSS EP LEATHERBACK CONSERVATION ISSUES AND POLICY ISSUES TO ADDRESS LEATHERBACK FISHERIES BYCATCH; AND (4) COORDINATE ONE EP LEATHERBACK NETWORK WORKSHOP ANNUALLY TO REVIEW ONGOING PROJECTS AND ACTIVITIES AND CONSULT ABOUT PROBLEMS AND NEEDS.

THE MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION FUND IS SOLICITING PROPOSALS FOR THE CONSERVATION OF MARINE TURTLES (CHELONIA MYDAS, CARETTA CARETTA, DERMOCHELYS CORIACEA, ERETMOCHELYS IMBRICATA, LEPIDOCHELYS OLIVACEA, LEPIDOCHELYS KEMPII) THROUGHOUT THEIR RANGE OUTSIDE OF THE UNITED STATES AND ITS TERRITORIES.  THE U.S. GOVERNMENT ENACTED THE MARINE TURTLE CONSERVATION ACT (MTCA) OF 2004 IN RESPONSE TO THE DECLINE OF MANY MARINE TURTLE POPULATIONS WORLDWIDE AND THE SERIOUS THREATS TO THEIR LONG-TERM SURVIVAL. THE PRIMARY PURPOSE OF THE ACT IS TO PROVIDE FINANCIAL SUPPORT FOR PROJECTS THAT CONSERVE NESTING POPULATIONS AND HABITAT AND ADDRESS OTHER THREATS TO THE SURVIVAL OF MARINE TURTLES IN FOREIGN COUNTRIES.
